transcripts.text: Right now, I'm in Brooksville, Florida, riding through 3,800 acres of land, all owned by the largest historically Black college in Florida, and that's FAMU.  Now, Brooksville, Florida, back in the day, they're historically known for not being so welcoming to Blacks.  But Brooksville, Florida today is a place where Black farmers are flourishing.  It took a while to break generational obstacles that kept many black farmers fighting for land they already own.
I've been on one farm for 42 years, and they just put a new road through it, and they already started building houses on it, so I'm limited there.
Road construction projects like the one Florida farmer Thomas Nichols described make for barren outcomes for black farmers.
We lost six About 100 acres this year.  And he already told me we're going to lose probably 114 or 15 acres next year.

Nichols said many black farmers lose their land this way, with other stories ranging from taxes on land going unpaid by younger generations to the state ending up in control of the land when families don't create a will.

That's the situation that black farmers have right now is the land.  and we don't own a lot of land.  You probably could take 100 acres and do a little bit of vegetables and stuff like that, but you can't grow many cows on 100 acres.  It takes about three, three acres up to raise one cow.
And it takes money to acquire the land.
The banks really don't want to let you have no money.  You got to have so much collateral in order to even borrow money.
Nichols added that his luck changed after he joined the Black Farmers Association.
I think this is a win-win situation down here for the black farmers.

The Black Farmer and Agriculturalist Association Florida chapter was started by Latresha Wilson after she came home from college and found that black farmers were not as successful as they once were.  The Center for American Progress found that the average full-time white farmer made just over $17,000 in farm income in 2017, while the average full-time African-American farmer made $2,400.

It's hard for a farmer just getting started if he don't have somebody like me to help him along the way until he gets his toe hope.  And it's not going to happen with a farmer that don't have a dad or got someone to let him, to finance him until he gets started.  It just costs too much.
Is it different than it used to be?
I started farming probably before I even knew it.  We had a mule.  And then we had tractors.  You could buy a tractor for $1,500, $2,000.  One just to get by with.
How much are they today?
This tractor right here behind me is probably about 110,000.

But now the Black Farmers Association has 3,800 acres of land and resources in Brooksville, Florida, and that is all for black farmers to utilize.  This after partnering with Florida Agriculture and Mechanical University to provide resources for veteran farmers and the tools for success for those incoming farmers.  But the leaders of the association say the real benefit is the generational wealth that this land will create for future black farmers like Ferris Brown.

I'm a third generation on one side and a fourth generation on the other.  And growing up, there was nothing else I'd rather do.  I mean, it gives you a sense of accomplishment when you see your product go to market.  It's just great to be out in the wide open spaces, you know.

Brown is a young farmer who takes pride in the land.  He is also one of the youngest members in the Black Farmers Association.  While soaking up the older generation's knowledge, he brings a young and fresh perspective to the table to show how farmers can survive in today's climate.

Blacks were responsible for doing most of the farming up to a certain point, and then, you know, our counterparts took it over, but we're still here.  We're still going strong.  And I hope that there's some young generation or some younger generations out there that want to do this.
But Brown told Atlanta Black Star that it's bigger than him.

The importance is for all the young black males that are growing up in America to know that there's still a black man out there riding their tractor, planting crops, working livestock.  And if they want to be like them, then it shows them that it can be done.
Ashanti Ford, Atlanta Black Star.
